reviewText: It's great to see a movie go in the direction of real life - the director could have taken this film in a obvious and predictable path - instead you get a story of how the hand of life is really dealt -look forward to more from Matt Muir

Attractively photographed and fascinating look at the music biz and the Austin scene.  The camera loves James Hand who could have a successful 2nd career as an actor with his expressive face and distinctive voice. It's nice that the film shows the range of music in Austin, but it would be good to have more than just an introduction to Hand's work as he is a genius songwriter and living legend of Texas honky-tonk. For more, check him out on web, Itunes and Youtube.

I grew up at the old home that  was used in the film and  wanted it just for family history's  sake. I was disappointed with the story line. It just wasn't exciting and the ending was a little flat. But I'm sure it was a good experience and I'm sure the next film will be better.

James Hand- 5 Stars for his role.
The Movie - 3.5 Stars The story should have been more about James and less about the character of his son and all his woes.
Soundtrack 2.5 Stars- There should have been a James Hand Album fir the Soundtrack

It was worth the money.

The premise is sold but the pace is too slow and the singer's son is not well cast. I think he is the wrong actor for the part.
Terrible!  No story line, and their "famous Singer"  CAN'T SING! ! !  So called singing was LOUD and OFF KEY !  Really horrible !  Complete waste of time.
loved the story; it kept me intrigued by what was going to happen next! And the characters are wonderful!
At the start of the movie, James had his back to the viewer and reminisces about audiences past, then says 1 2 3 hit it Will and I started to cry. Anyone who knew Will Indian will know why.
It was an ok movie but not what I expeced
